Name: Pentaerythritol
Description: Pentaerythritol is a tetrol that is neopentane in which one of the methyl hydrogens of all four methyl groups are replaced by hydroxy groups. It is a chemical intermediate used in the production of explosives, plastics, paints, appliances, and cosmetics. It has a role as a flame retardant and a laxative. It is a primary alcohol and a tetrol. It derives from a hydride of a neopentane.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html as of Jan 19, 2010. (2) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: Values for BCF of 0.3-0.6 and 0.2-2.1 were calculated in fish for pentaerythritol(SRC), using carp (Cyprinus carpio) which were exposed 10 and 1 ppm pentaerythritol, respectively, over an 6-week period(1). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html as of Jan 19, 2010. (2) Kaiser KLE; Water Qual Res J Can 33: 1 85-211 (1998)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Pentaerythritol, present at 100 mg/L, reached 13.2% of its theoretical BOD in 25 days using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test(1). Aerobic biodegradation test results for pentaerythritol with other biodegradation tests do show varying results: 97% DOC, 14 days, Zahn-Wellens; 0% DOC, 28 days, AFNOR; 9% CO2, Sturm test; 43%DOC Sturm test; OECD 301B, 77% removal; OECD 301 E modified screening test, 30 days, 13-97% DOC; OECD 302, 30 days, activated sludge, 98% degradation(2).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Gerike P, Fischer WK; Ecotoxicol Environ Safety 3: 159-73 (1979) (2) Gerike P, Fischer WK; Ecotoxicol Environ Safety 5: 45-55 (1981) (3) Ilic P; Z Wasser Abwasser Forsch 11: 77-81 (1978) (4) Ludzack FJ, Ettinger MB; J Water Pollut Control Fed 32: 1173-200 (1960) (5) Mohanrao GJ, McKinney RE; Int J Air Pollut 6: 153 (1962) (6) Struijs J, Stoltenkamp; Ecotoxicol Environ Safety 19: 204-11 (1990)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: There is conflicting reports about the aerobic biodegradability of pentaerythritol in the literature. While some authors observed little or no biodegradation of pentaerythritol by their test methods(3-6), other investigators noted that the compound will readily biodegrade under certain test conditions(1-2). Most of the discrepancies in the results are due to the different conditions used in the test methods, such as difference in inocula, acclimation of inocula, period of incubation and the test methods used to measure biodegradation(1-2).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Painter HA, King EF; Ecotoxicol Environ Safety 9: 6-16 (1985) (2) Birch RR, Fletcher RJ; Chemosphere 23: 855-72 (1991) (3) Kuenemann P et al; Chemosphere 24: 63-9 (1992)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: When a modified Sturm test was used to determine the biodegradability, pentaerythritol showed 53-59% biodegradation on the basis of evolved carbon dioxide but biodegradation was 96-97% based on DOC removal(3) under otherwise similar conditions. The difference between the two test methods is that while the COD method did account for the carbon loss due to assimilation by the bacteria as biomass, the carbon dioxide evolution method did not(3). The lag or delay time for the biodegradation of pentaerythritol has been reported to be 3 to 15 days(1). Besides acclimation of the bacteria, an optimum concn of viable cells may be required for the biodegradation of pentaerythritol and this number is on the order of 10,000 viable cells/L(2).

AEROBIC: Pentaerythritol, present at 34.3 mg/L, was 97% degraded in 40 days following a 21-day lag period using a seawater inoculum from the Sea of Kattegat sampled north of Hundested, Denmark (21% salinity, collected May 21, 1985) and the shake flask screening test, incubated at 15 °C(1).
ANAEROBIC: Pentaerythritol is amenable to anaerobic biodegradation(1).

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. 3rd ed., Volumes 1-26. New York, NY: John Wiley and Sons, 1978-1984., p. VI 779 (1978)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ At doses 20 g/kg for guinea pigs and 40 g/kg for albino rats (sex unknown), no serious ill effects, other than a laxative effect, were noticed.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; Screening Information Data Set for Pentaerythritol (CAS # 115-77-5) p. 290 (October 1998). Available from, as of February 2, 2010: https://www.inchem.org/documents/sids/sids/115775.pdf
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ A saturated aqueous solution of pentaerythritol /was/ instilled into the rabbit eye (strain unknown). As a result, no irritation or inflammation was observed. However, instillation of a 50% aqueous suspension into the conjunctival sac resulted in slight irritation. The signs of ocular irritation resolved within 24 hours.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists. Documentation of the TLV's and  BEI's with Other World Wide Occupational Exposure Values. CD-ROM Cincinnati, OH 45240-1634  2009.
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ In rats, dogs, and guinea pigs exposed 6 hr daily for 90 days ... Rats survived oral doses ... 16 g/kg ... Signs of toxicity were diarrhea (rats at 5 g/kg) and tremors, ataxia, and loss of righting reflex at higher doses.

/LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ A twenty-eight-day repeated dose toxicity test of pentaerythritol at dose levels of 1000 or 0 mg/kg/day was carried out in male and female F344 rats. Thirteen animals of each sex were divided into 2 groups with 7 rats receiving pentaerythritol treatment and 6 rats served saline as control. All groups received an intragastric administration daily for 28 days. As to serum biochemical and hematological examinations, there were no serious differences between the pentaerythritol-treated rats and the control rats. On histopathological examination, no specific changes were observed in the pentaerythritol-treated rats. Based on these results, the no-observed-effect level of pentaerythritol can be concluded to be more than 1000 mg/kg/day.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists. Documentation of the TLV's and  BEI's with Other World Wide Occupational Exposure Values. CD-ROM Cincinnati, OH 45240-1634  2009.
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ /Application/ of a saturated aqueous solution of technical pentaerythritol once daily for 10 days to rabbit skin failed to elicit any significant irritation.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; Screening Information Data Set for Pentaerythritol (CAS # 115-77-5) p. 291 (October 1998). Available from, as of February 2, 2010: https://www.inchem.org/documents/sids/sids/115775.pdf
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ Oral toxicity study of pentaerythritol was performed in SD(Crj:CD) rats (sex unknonwn) by an OECD combined repeat dose and reproductive/developmental toxicity screening test at doses of 0 (vehicle: 0.5 % CMC-Na), 100, 300, 1000 mg/kg/day. Soft feces were noted in both sexes of the 300 and 1000 mg/kg groups, and diarrhea was noted in males of the 300 and 1000 mg/kg groups and females of the 1000 mg/kg group. Water consumption increased in males of the 1000 mg/kg group. No effects were observed in body weights, food consumption, urinalysis, hematology, blood chemistry, organ weight, autopsy or histopathology findings. NOEL was considered to be 100 mg/kg/day based on gastrointestinal changes.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; Screening Information Data Set for Pentaerythritol (CAS # 115-77-5) p. 291 (October 1998). Available from, as of February 2, 2010: https://www.inchem.org/documents/sids/sids/115775.pdf
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ Inhalation toxicity study for 90 days was performed in rats, guinea pigs and dogs (sex, strain and breed of test animals unknown) at a concentration of 8 g/cu m /SRP: these doses appear to be incorrect/ (as a mixture of 88% mono- and 12% dipentaerythritol), 6 hours/day. No effect was observed in reaction, body weights, mortality, hematologic studies, and gross and microscopic pathologic studies. A concentration of 8 g/cu m was NOEL for three experimental animals.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; Screening Information Data Set for Pentaerythritol (CAS # 115-77-5) p. 291 (October 1998). Available from, as of February 2, 2010: https://www.inchem.org/documents/sids/sids/115775.pdf
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ Oral toxicity study of pentaerythritol was performed in SD(Crj:CD) rats by an OECD combined repeat dose and reproductive/developmental toxicity screening test at doses of 0 (vehicle: 0.5% CMC-Na), 100, 300, 1000 mg/kg/day. No effects were observed on the following items: for dams, reproductive ability, organ weights, histopathological appearance of the reproductive organs, delivery or maternal behavior, and for offspring, viability, clinical signs, body weight changes or autopsy findings. The NOELs for reproductive and developmental performances were considered to be 1000 mg/kg/day.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; Screening Information Data Set for Pentaerythritol (CAS # 115-77-5) p. 291 (October 1998). Available from, as of February 2, 2010: https://www.inchem.org/documents/sids/sids/115775.pdf
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ Gene reverse mutation was negative in S. typhimurium TA100, TA98, TA1535, TA1537, and Escherichia coli WP2 uvrA with and without metabolic activation. Neither structural chromosomal aberrations nor polyploidy were induced in CHL/IU cells up to the concentration of 1.4 mg/mL, in the absence or presence of an exogenous metabolic activation system.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Walton JR, Davis EM; Toxicology and Fate of Selected Industrial Chemicals in Aquatic Ecosystems. Celanese Chemical Company, Inc; USEPA/OPTS Public Files; Doc#:878213535; TSCATS Fiche#: OTS0205849 (1980) (2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.0. Jan, 2009. Available from https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm as of Jan 19, 2010. (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of pentaerythritol is estimated as 1.5(SRC), using a log Kow of -1.69(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this estimated Koc value suggests that pentaerythritol is expected to have very high mobility in soil.
